text:
Bowling Green 1835
Photograph by Brown Brothers
220 West 42nd St.
New York City

folder: State Street & Bowling Green Row, Manhattan, NY
text:
State Street, east side, south from Bowling Green Row to Pearl Street, showing a row of fashionable homes facing on Battery Park (right). Shown in the foreground, is No. 7 Bowling Green, at the S.E. corner of State Street. The farthest building shown, is Stewart's Store, (predecessor to John Wanamaker in the Department Store line), which occupied the block between Bridge and Pearl Streets. Stephen Whitney resided in one of the houses facing Bowling Green. Today (1937), the U.S. Custom House rises here on the area shown in the foreground, with the 12-story Battery Park Building (former Stewart site) at its rear. About 1860.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: State Street - Bowling Green Row

text:
1-- Bowling Green, a northward view up Broadway from "Steamboat Row", showing a view of New York's first park. Note the iron railing around same and the lanterns thereupon. In the center is a pool and fountain.

Early views (circa 1850 and 61) show this latter feature and which in subsequent views (1884) is absent, tho the pool remained. The last date given is that of Produce Exchange Building construction, replacing the buildings on the right.

To the left on Broadway, appear ovate shaped sewer pipes and a partial excavation for same. These were introduced in 1860 and were 4x2.8 feet in diameter. In 1864 vitrified pipe was first laid. Across the foreground are suspended electric wires and at the extreme right is an old street illuminating gas lamp.

For dedication ceremony (April 6, 1938) see New York City newspapers for February and March. Views similar to this are in these files and in a volume of newspaper clippings titled "New York City Views" American History Division - Room 300 New York Public Library, several of which are credited to the Consolidated Edison Company.

Rockwood Photo

2-- Broadway north from Bowling Green

Thadéus Wilderson
522 W. 145th Street
New York City
about 1900

Bowling Green, at the foot of Broadway, showing an early and a late view. View 2 is north on Broadway.

View 1: 1871
View 2: 1920's

Bowling Green, at the foot of Broadway, showing an early and a late view. View 2 is north on Broadway.

View 1: 1871
View 2: 1920's

Bowling Green: New York's first park photographed southward down Broadway. This thoroughfare is on the right and Battery Park is just beyond. Buildings appearing through the trees are units of the former residences that now form "Steamship Row." Above same, in the Upper Bay, lies Governor's Island.

About 1875

Roege, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing mainly the westerly side of this thoroughfare and its Trinity Church at Wall Street.

1876

Roege, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

Bowling Green: Two old views of the Bowling Green Park, one being north up Broadway (view 1) and the other south, across the site where the Custom House was later erected.
1880's
Views 1,2

Broadway, north from Bowling Green. Trinity Church is shown on the west side of Broadway, north of Rector Street. In the foreground, appears a Broadway street car; drawn by horses. note gas lights on street and overhead wire communications.

About 1882.

W. Gray.
New York Edison Company.

Bowling Green Park: New Yorks first park, located at the foot of Broadway. The buildings in the background are upon the west side of that thoroughfare, extending between Battery Place (left) and Morris Street (right). The Columbia Building stands at the N. W. corner of the latter point. To the north is the Aldrich Court.

About 1885

Gift of the Urbrock Collection

(1)

Bowling Green South, east from and including State Street, to and including Broadway. Also shown is State Street, east side, south from Bowling Green South, to but not including Bridge Street. Bowling Green South was known as Steamship Row, and is now the
present site for the Custom House.
About 1885.

Brown Brothers.

(2)

The same, about forty-five years later, showing the United States Custom House with Bowling Green in the foreground. Also shown is Broadway, east side, south from but not including Beaver Street.

June 6, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)

Broadway), the eastern boundary of the Green.
October 13, 1930.

#2 Battery Place, North West corner of Broadway, to and including Greenwich Street, showing the Washington Building. Note Battery Place Station at Greenwich Street of the Sixth and Ninth Avenue Elevated. The building was completed in 1884 and is 13 stories in height.

January 1886.

Wurts Bros. General Photographers,
1368 Broadway, corner 36th St.

Broadway, east side, north from Bowling Green and showing prominently the Seaboard National Bank (No. 18) and the Standard Oil Building (No. 26). Subsequently, this latter corporation purchased the Bank site and erected upon same. Kings Hand book of New York, 1892, carries an account of this financial institution and a similar illustration on page 692.

1889.

Brown Brothers.

Broadway, north from new Battery Place. In the background is Trinity Church.
1890's
views 1,2

Bowling Green, a small park on Broadway at Battery Place, as seen when viewed northward on Broadway. The spire shown on the west side of Broadway, is that of Trinity Church, which faces Wall Street. The buildings shown on the right, are at and adjoining the N.E. corner of Beaver Street, and to-day (1937), the Standard Oil Building occupies this site.

1891
Brown Brothers.

Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing prominently the easterly side of this thoroughfare. On the right appears the Standard Oil Building and the adjoining Seaboard National Bank. For details and a comparative illustration see King's Handbook of New York--pages 143 and 692.

About 1895

Gift Thru New York Historical Society

(1) Bowling Green, east from Broadway showing "Steam- ship Row" and the Produce Exchange Building. The Custom House replaced the former. The decorations may be for the Admiral Dewey Celebration.

About 1899

Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing prominently on the east side (right) the 16 story Standard Oil Building, No. 26. On the left appears the 17 story Bowling Green Building, No. 5-11.

Ewing Galloway

1899

No. 2 Battery Place, north side, west from Broadway, to and including Greenwich Street, showing the Washington Building. Note the Battery Place Station of the Sixth and Ninth Ave., Elevated on Greenwich Street. The Hudson River is shown in the background, with the Jersey Shore faintly visible.

About 1900.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

"The houses at Bowling Green" p.157

Pelletreau, William S.

Broadway, Nos.1-11

Early New York houses with historical - genealogical notes.
New York: Francis P. Harper, 1900.

Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing the foot of this important Manhattan thoroughfare. The City's first park, the Green, is in the center behind the street car. The buildings there are on the east side and were later replaced with the outstanding Standard Oil Building. At the left margin is No. 1 Broadway.

About 1900

Thomas W. Kennedy, photo
Thru Beecher Ogden
Museum Photo. Assn.

(1)
Nos. 1, 5-11 and 13 to 27 Broadway, west side, north from Battery Place (left) to Morris Street (right) as seen across Bowling Oreen. Twe 12-story structure on the left (No. 1) is the Washington Building. Adjacent to same is the 17-story Bowling Green Building, No. 5-11. At the S.W. corner of Morris Street is the 5-story Stevens House, No. 21-27. Across the roof of the latter appears the south side of the 12-story Columbia Building, No. 29 Broadway, at the N.W. corner
of Morris Street.
September 25, 1906.
Brown Brothers.
  NEG # 4281
(2)
The same in a southward direction (from Morris Street to Battery Place). Note on the extreme left the Custom House under construction.
May 2, 1904.
Brown Brothers.

Bowling Green viewed northward from Battery Place (in Views 1-2-3) showing the point where Broadway begins its existance. Note the old horse car in view 1.

Views 2-3-4 were taken to show the completion of the track removal by the W.P.A. This agency also rehabilitated the park and its famous railing.

George L. Balgue

W. P. A. Photo
Five Borouths Project

View 1: Nov. 1905
View 2-3-4: February 7, 1937

About 1905.

Brown Brothers.

Same per as glossy labelled Sept. 20, 1906.

Broadway, north from Bowling Green, with Battery Place on the left, and Beaver Street on the right, and showing mainly the east side of Broadway across Bowling Green.

September 20, 1906.

Bowling Green, at the foot of Broadway, showing the U. S. Custom House there, as photographed across Bowling Green Park. To the left of same is Whitehall Street. On the right is State Street and Battery Park.

No. 1 Broadway, at the N.W. corner of Battery Place, showing the dome of the Washington Building as viewed in a southward direction from the Bowling Green Building. In addition appears a portion of Battery Park and the Upper Bay. This set consists of a negative and a positive.

July 27, 1920.

Irving Underhill.
Gift of Albert A. Volk Co.

Broadway, north from and including Battery Place.
About 1925.

Brown Brothers.

Broadway, north from both Battery Place and Beaver Street. (At the left is Battery Place and at the right is Beaver Street. This view shows Bowling Green in the centre foreground, which was originally used by the Dutch, for bowling and a drinking place, a refuge from their respective domestic havens.

About 1925.

(1)
Broadway, north from Bowling Green as viewed across Battery Park (immediate foreground) and from the station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line.

May 24, 1926.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

November 23, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway, north from Bowling Green.
1926.
Brown Brothers.

Broadway, north from Bowling Green. The intersection shown on the right, is Beaver Street, with the 7-story Produce Building at the S.E. corner. The towered Standard Oil Co. Building (Nos. 8 to 26 Broadway) occupies the N.E. corner. Prominent buildings shown on the left, (west side of Broadway), and in the order of their appearance are the: Washington, Bowling Green, Cunard, Columbia, Adams, American Railway Express Co., Empire, Trinity and Singer.

September 1926.

Brown Brothers.

Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing the start of this thoroughfare that traverses the entire island.
September 1926.

Brown Brothers.

Broadway, north from Bowling Green, with Battery Place on the left, and Beaver Street on the right. Sandwiched between these building giants, is Bowling Green, the first public park in Manhattan, surrounding which stood the homes of Lord Cornwallis, Lord Howe, Sir Henry Clinton, George Washington, General Gates, Benedict Arnold, Talleyrand and other famous personages of American History. To-day (1937), we find encompassing same, the Washington, Bowling Green, and Cunard Buildings, on the west side of Broadway, and facing the curved Standard Oil Co. Building. On the right, a portion of the U.S. Custom House obstructs a view of the Produce Exchange Building. The spired edifices in the background, are the Singer and Woolworth Buildings.

February 4, 1927.

New York Edison Company.

Bowling Green and the U.S. Custom House, as viewed southward along Broadway. Shown on the right, the west side of Broadway, and in the order of their appearance are, the Cunard Building, the Bowling Green Building, the Washington Building and Battery Park. The curved building on the opposite side, is Nos. 8-26 Broadway, the Standard Oil Company Building.

February 21, 1928

N. Y. Edison Company.

(1) Broadway, north from Battery Place, showing at the left, the Washington Building (N.W. corner of Battery Place) and at the right the curved structure of the Standard Oil Co. (N.E. corner of Beaver Street). Note the Woolworth Building, up Broadway. May 1929.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) The tower atop the Standard Oil Building as viewed in a northward direction from the Produce Exchange Building. Broadway is on the left. August 28, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) Broadway, north from Battery Place, showing at the left, the Washington Building (N.W. corner of Battery Place) and at the right the curved structure of the Standard Oil Co. (N.E. corner of Beaver Street). Note the Woolworth Building, up Broadway. May 1929.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) The tower atop the Standard Oil Building as viewed in a northward direction from the Produce Exchange Building. Broadway is on the left. August 28, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green (right) and showing mainly the west side (left) of same. Note the apple vendors in front of the Cunard Building. This was a feature of the early phases of the Depression. This set consists of 2 views.

About 1930.

Broadway, north from Bowling Green (right) and showing mainly the west side (left) of same. Note the apple vendors in front of the Cunard Building. This was a feature of the early phases of the Depression. This set consists of 2 views.

July 23, 1936

frontispiece, Changing New York

(1)
Bowling Green: (A small triangular plot on the northern confines of Battery Park), at the southern terminus of Broadway. Shown in the Green, and facing the Custom House, is the heroic statue of Abraham Depyster the great-grandfather of Philip Van Cortlandt.

June 25, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing W.P.A. employees engaged in a street car track removal project. Note the Republican campaign banner suspended across Broadway, soliciting the financial and clerical workers of this district to vote for their presidential candidate, who as it eventually evolved, failed to be elected; Franklin D. Roosevelt gaining a second term.

August 25, 1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

Broadway, at Bowling Green; viewed northward from the U. S. Custom House. Dominant on the right is the Standard Oil Building. Opposed to same are the Cunard, Columbia and Fred F. French Buildings.

1938-9

Alexander Alland

This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

folder: Broadway #2 - Bowling Green, looking southeast, Manhattan, NY
title: Broadway #2 - Bowling Green, looking southeast

text: "Gateway to New World" Custom House is one side of opening and International Mercantile Marine Building on other.

Bowling Green, Manhattan

n.d.
New home of International Mercantile & Marine Company at 1 Broadway.

Hans W. Hannau, photographer
#1001

Broadway, north from Battery Place, across Bowling Green. On left is the old-type Washington Building, in the immediate foreground is the United States Custom House under construction.

Ewing Galloway
no date
